https://doi.org/10.18653/v1/P17-2082  1 Introduction  Recently, the Relation Extraction (RE) task has attracted the attention of many researchers due to its wide range of applications such as question answering, text summarization and bio-medical text mining.
body_sentences.2: The aim of this task is to identify the type of relation between two entities in a given text.
body_sentences.3: Most work on RE has mainly regarded the application of supervised methods, which require costly annotation, especially for large-scale datasets.
body_sentences.4: To overcome the annotation problem, Craven et al.
body_sentences.5: (1999) firstly proposed to collect automatic annotation through Distant Supervision (DS).
body_sentences.6: In the DS setting, the training data for RE is often automatically annotated utilizing an external Knowledge-Base (KB) such as Wikipedia or Freebase (Hoffmann et al., 2010; Riedel et al., 2010; Nguyen and Moschitti, 2011).
body_sentences.7:
Although DS has
shown to be promising for RE, it also produces many noisy labels in the automatic annotated data, which deteriorate the performance of the system trained on it.
body_sentences.9: (2011) showed that by simply adding a small set of high quality labeled instances (i.e., human-annotated training data) to a larger set of instances annotated by DS, makes the overall precision of the system significantly increases.
body_sentences.10: Such level of quality of the labels usually can be obtained at low cost via crowdsourcing.
body_sentences.11: However, this finding does not hold for more complex tasks, where the annotators1 need to have some expertise on them.
body_sentences.12: For instance in RE, several works have shown that only a marginal improvement can be achieved via crowdsourcing the data (Angeli et al., 2014; Zhang et al., 2012; Pershina et al., 2014).
body_sentences.13: In such papers, the wellknown Gold Standard quality control mechanism was used without annotators being trained.
body_sentences.14: Very recently, despite the previous results, Liu et al.
body_sentences.15: (2016) showed a larger improvement for the RE task when training crowd workers in an interactive tutorial procedure called “Gated Instruction”.
body_sentences.16: This approach, however, requires a set of high-quality labeled data (i.e., the Gold Standard) for providing the instruction and feedback to the crowd workers.
body_sentences.17: However, acquiring such data requires a considerable amount of human effort.
body_sentences.18: In this paper, we propose to alternatively use Silver Standard, i.e., a high-quality automatic annotated data, to train the crowd workers.
body_sentences.19: Specifically, we introduce a self-training strategy for crowd-sourcing, where the workers are first trained with simpler examples (which we assume to be less noisy) and then gradually presented with more difficult ones.
body_sentences.20:
This is biologically inspired by the common human process of gradual learn-

body_sentences.22: Moreover, we propose an iterative humanmachine co-training framework for the task of RE.
body_sentences.23: The main idea is (i) to automatically select a subset of less-noisy examples applying an automatic classifier, (ii) training the annotators with such subset, and (iii) iterating this process after retraining the classifiers using the annotated data.
body_sentences.24: That is, the educated crowd workers can provide higher quality annotations, which can be used by the system in the next iteration to improve the quality of its classification.
body_sentences.25: In other words, this cycle gradually improves both system and human annotators.
body_sentences.26: This is in line with the studies in human-based computational approaches, which showed that the crowd intelligence can effectively alleviate the drifting problem in auto-annotation systems (Sun et al., 2014; Russakovsky et al., 2015).
body_sentences.27: Our study shows that even without using any gold standard, we can still train workers and their annotations can achieve results comparable with the more costly state-of-the-art methods.
body_sentences.28:
In summary our contributions are the following:
• we introduce a self-training strategy for crowdsourcing;
• we propose an iterative human-machine cotraining framework for the task of RE; and
• we test our approach on a standard benchmark, obtaining a slightly lower performance compared to the state-of-the-art methods based on Gold Standard data.
body_sentences.29: This study opens up avenues for exploiting inexpensive crowdsourcing solutions similar to ours to achieve performance gain in NLP tasks.
body_sentences.30: 2 Background Work  There is a large body of work on DS for RE, but we only discuss the most related to our work and refer the reader to other recent work (Wu and Weld, 2007; Mintz et al., 2009; Bunescu, 2007; Hoffmann et al., 2010; Riedel et al., 2010; Surdeanu et al., 2012; Nguyen and Moschitti, 2011).
body_sentences.31: Many researchers have exploited the techniques of combining the DS data with small human annotated data collected via crowdsourcing, to improve the relation extractor accuracy (Liu et al., 2016; Angeli et al., 2014; Zhang et al., 2012).
body_sentences.33: (2014) reported a minor improvement using active learning methods to select the best instances to be crowdsourced.
body_sentences.34: In the same direction, Zhang et al.
body_sentences.35: (2012) studied the effect of providing human feedback in crowdsourcing tasks and observed a minor improvement in terms of F1.
body_sentences.36: At high level, our work may be viewed as employing crowdsourcing for RE.
body_sentences.37: In that spirit, we are similar to these works, but with the main difference of training crowd workers to obtain higher quality annotations.
body_sentences.38: The most related paper to our work is by Liu et al.
body_sentences.39: (2016), who trained the crowd workers via “Gated Instruction”.
body_sentences.40: They also showed that collecting higher-quality annotations can be achieved through training the workers.
body_sentences.41: The produced data also improved the performance of the RE systems trained on it.
body_sentences.43: However, unlike them, we do not employ any Gold Standard (annotated by experts) for training the annotators and instead we propose a self-training strategy to select a set of high-quality automatic annotated data (namely, Silver Standard).
body_sentences.44: 3 Self-Crowdsourcing Training  In this section we first explain, our proposed method for automatically identifying high-quality examples (i.e., Silver Standard) to train the crowd workers and collect annotations for the lowerquality examples.
body_sentences.45: We then explain the scheme designed for crowd worker training and annotation collection.
body_sentences.46: 3.1 Silver Standard Mining  The main idea of our approach to SelfCrowdsourcing training is to use the classifier’s score for gradually training the crowd workers, such that the examples and labels associated with the highest prediction values (i.e., the most reliable) will be used as Silver Standard.
body_sentences.47: More in detail, our approach is based on a noisy-label dataset, DS, whose labels are extracted in a distant supervision fashion and CS a dataset to be labeled by the crowd.
body_sentences.48: The first step is to divide CS into three parts: CSI , which is used to create the instructions for the crowd workers; CSQ, which is used for asking questions about sentence annotations; and CSA, which is used to collect the labels from annotators, after they have been trained.
body_sentences.49: To select CSI , we train a classifier C on DS, and then used it to label CS examples.
body_sentences.50: In particular, we used MultiR framework (Hoffmann et al., 2011) to train C, as it is a widely used framework for RE.
body_sentences.51: Then, we sort CS in a descending order according to the classifier prediction scores and select the first Ni elements, obtaining CSI .
body_sentences.52: Next, we select the Nq examples of CS \ CSI with the highest score to create the set CSQ.
body_sentences.53:
Note that the latter contains highly-reliable classifier annotations but since the scores are lower than for
CSI examples, we conjecture that they may be more difficult to be annotated by the crowd workers.
body_sentences.54: Finally, CSA is assigned with the remaining examples, i.e., CS \ CSI \ CSQ.
body_sentences.55: These have the lowest confidence and should therefore be annotated by crowd workers.
body_sentences.56: Ni and Nq can be tuned on the task, we set both to 10% of the data.

body_sentences.99: We compared our method with (i) the DS-only baseline and (ii) the state of the art, Gated Instruction (GI) strategy (Liu et al., 2016).
body_sentences.100: We emphasize that the same set of examples (both DS and CS) are used in this experiment and just replaced the GI annotations with the annotations collected using our proposed framework.
body_sentences.101: The results are shown in Table 1.
body_sentences.102: Our method improves the DS-only baseline by 7%, 5% and 2% (absolute) in Precision, Recall and F1, respectively.
body_sentences.103: This improvement clearly confirms the benefit of our fully automatic approach to crowdsourcing in RE task.
body_sentences.104: Additionally, our model is just 3% lower than the GI method in terms of F1.
body_sentences.105: In both our method and GI, the crowd workers are trained before enrolling in the main task.
body_sentences.106: However, GI trains annotators using Gold Standard data, which involves a higher level of supervision with respect to our method.
body_sentences.107: Thus our self-training method is potentially effective and an inexpensive alternative to GI.
body_sentences.108: We also analyzed the accuracy of the crowd workers in terms of the quality of their annotations.
body_sentences.109: For this purpose, we randomly selected 100 sentences from CSA and then had them manually annotated by an expert.
body_sentences.110: We compared the accuracy of the annotations collected with our proposed approach with those provided by DS-only baseline and the GI method.
body_sentences.111: Table 2 shows the results: the annotations performed by workers trained with our method are just slightly less accurate than the annotations produced by annotators trained with GI.
body_sentences.112: This outcome is inline with the positive impact of our good quality annotation on the RE performance.
body_sentences.113: 5 Conclusion  In this paper, we have proposed a self-training strategy for crowdsourcing as an effective alternative to train annotators with Gold Standard.
body_sentences.114: Our experimental results show that the annotations of workers trained with our method are accurate and produce a good performance when used in learning algorithms for RE.
body_sentences.115: Our study suggests that automatically training annotators can replace the popular consensus-based filtering scheme.
body_sentences.116: Our method achieves this goal through an inexpensive training procedure.
body_sentences.117: In the future, it would be interesting to study if our method generalizes to other difficult or even simpler tasks.
body_sentences.118:
In particular, our approach opens up many research directions on how to best train
workers or best select data for them, similarly to what active learning methods have been doing for training machines.
